entry.title: Re: Alternative BOM as a component
entry.content:
Hello @Halleyhaha 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

Managing Bills of Material from the Maintenance Order, Alternative Ways to Explode a Bill of Material, Selection Conditions, Use of the BOM Explosion Number

In summary, when working with multilevel BOMs containing alternative BOMs, the system will by default select alternatives 1 unless: a BOM Usage + Alternative Determination Rule is explicitly set, or a Production Version points to the correct alternative BOM.
 
Since your scenario involves a multilevel BOM structure and your lower-level (A1) has its own BOM alternatives, the system will not automatically inherit the parent-level BOM alternative selection.  In public cloud, this is designed to ensure consistent and predictable BOM explosion, especially when Variant Configuration is not active.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Beyond REST: Exploring GraphQL API Integration in SAP BTP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

GraphQL is transforming the way modern applications connect to and consume enterprise data, offering efficient and flexible querying  developers and integration designers. In SAP landscapes, this means you can consolidate complex integration flows and reduce payload size.

This article introduces GraphQL basics and demonstrates how to integrate SAP Cloud Integration with GraphQL APIs, delivering practical and step-by-step hands on you can apply to your own integration scenarios.

Recently I had an opportunity to work on an integration project where the customer extensively leveraged GraphQL APIs. That's where I thought sharing my experience will be helpful for developers to help in their GraphQL integration journey.

 

What is GraphQL?

Before we dive into actual integration flow, let us first try to understand some basics of GraphQL.

GraphQL is a query language for APIs that executes queries against a defined and a strongly-typed schema. Unlike traditional REST APIs that expose multiple endpoints for specific data objects, GraphQL APIs provide a single endpoint where clients can request exactly the fields they need, avoiding both over-fetching and under-fetching of data.

It is a schema based approach that gives the consumers of the APIs more control over the data retrieval at the same time making integrations more flexible, particularly in complex enterprise landscapes.

Before jumping on the GraphQL integration, first take a look at a sample GraphQL API (which I have also used in my demo)

Countries API: Explore country details such as languages, capitals, and regions.

  • Endpoint: https://countries.trevorblades.com/

  • Example Query 1: Fetch all countries.
query {
  countries {
    code
    name
    capital
    continent {
      name
    }
    languages {
      name
    }
  }
}
‚Äã
  • Example Query 2: Fetch country with code
query {
  country(code:"US") {
    code
    name
    capital
    continent {
      name
    }
    languages {
      name
    }
  }
}

In the above two examples, if you see the API endpoint remains same but the query changes based on the desired response. You can add or remove attributes from the query section.

Try out by yourself and you will understand the basics quickly.

 

The Core Challenges

Unlike OData or SOAP, there isn‚Äôt a native GraphQL adapter available in SAP BTP Cloud Integration. This means you can‚Äôt directly select a ‚ÄúGraphQL‚Äù protocol from the standard adapter list when configuring your integration flows. 

Good News: We can leverage standard HTTP adapter for this type of integration.

You must also set appropriate HTTP headers (such as Content-Type, authentication/tokens etc.). Parsing the flexible GraphQL responses often involves extra effort during mapping or transformation compared to protocol-specific adapters.

Another challenge is that as GraphQL provides flexible schema, there is often no OpenAPI or Swagger specifications available for these APIs. This makes integration highly adaptable but developers have to rely on documentation instead of OpenAPI contract like YAML file. Which means you may not be able to directly use standard message mappings directly.

Good News: We can leverage converters (JSON to XML) and groovy scripting extensively to handle transformations and message processing.

 

Real World Use Case

I tackled a real-world scenario which I will explain briefly. The use case centered around synchronizing stock levels between an e-commerce platform and SAP S/4HANA.

  • Whenever the e-commerce marketplace detects an order change, it sends a notification event to the integration flow.

  • The flow receives this event and extracts the order code from the notification event.

  • Using this order code, the flow triggers a GraphQL API call to fetch up-to-date order details for that order code from the customer e-commerce platform.

  • The retrieved order information is then mapped to the corresponding SAP S/4HANA object, enabling an accurate and timely order data integrity within the ERP system.

This integration ensures both systems remain aligned and allows real-time order data synchronization based on event-based design.

To simulate this integration, I used a similar workflow, but using the countries GraphQL API to explain the integration.

 

Integration Flow Walkthrough

In this section, I will walk you through the integration flow (iFlow) to connect SAP BTP Cloud Integration with a GraphQL API. Below is a screenshot of the iFlow design, highlighting the main components involved in orchestrating the request and handling the response.

Figure-1: Integration Flow

We will break down main steps to understand:

  1. How the flow is structured
  2. How the HTTP adapter is configured
  3. How message processing and data mapping are managed for GraphQL integration
  • Groovy Scripting: Groovy gives control for creating GraphQL request. Here is a sample groovy script which I have used
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;
import groovy.json.JsonBuilder;

def Message processData(Message message) 
{
	def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;
	def jsonInput = new JsonSlurper().parseText(body);

	if(!jsonInput) {
		throw new IllegalArgumentException("Input payload is empty or null");
	}
	
	def countryCode = (jsonInput.countryCode != null) ? jsonInput.countryCode : "IN";

	def graphQLQuery = """query {
  		country(code: "${countryCode}") {
  		  name
  		  native
  		  capital
  		  currency
  		  languages {
  		    name
  		  }
  		}
	}""";
	
	// Convert the GraphQL query into a JSON payload and set it as message body
    def jsonBody = new JsonBuilder([query: graphQLQuery]).toString()
    message.setBody(jsonBody)
	message.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");

	//log message body
	def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
	if(messageLog != null) {
		messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("GraphQL Request Body", jsonBody, "text/plain");
	}

	return message;
}‚Äã

  • HTTP Adapter: Use standard HTTP adapter to provide GraphQL API endpoint, authentication, additional headers etc. In this POC, I have skipped the authentication piece as our main focus is GraphQL API integration.

  • JSON to XML Converter: After getting the JSON response, leverage the JSON to XML converter to get the XML payload.

  • Message Mapping: Once you get the sample XML, generate an XSD using XSD generator tools. This XSD can be used as a source XSD in the message mapping component. The target XSD is the one which you can get the the target API schema (Either SOAP Or OData) 

I have provided the integration flows in my GitHub

Take time to download the package, deploy it in your tenant and give it a try.

 

Mutations

In the above integration flow, I have only shown how to get the data using GraphQL APIs. But in real world you might also be required to create or update data. The countries GraphQL API is READ ONLY but I will explain theoretically how we can accomplish it in a groovy which you can use it as reference (provided your API supports it).

Suppose I want to update capital name of any country.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;
import groovy.json.JsonBuilder;

def String getGraphQLQuery() {
    return '''
    mutation UpdateCountryCapital($input: UpdateCountryInput!) {
      updateCountryCapital(input: $input) {
        code
        name
        capital
      }
    }
    '''
}

def Message processData(Message message) 
{
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String
    def inputJson = new JsonSlurper().parseText(body)
    if (!inputJson) {
        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Input payload is empty or null");
    }
    // Compose the input for GraphQL variables
    def inputMap = [
        code: inputJson.code,
        capital: inputJson.capital
    ]

    // Build the GraphQL mutation payload
    def graphQLBody = [
        query: getGraphQLQuery(),
        variables: [input: inputMap]
    ]
    def jsonBody = new JsonBuilder(graphQLBody).toString()
    message.setBody(jsonBody)
    message.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");

    // Optional: log message body
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    if(messageLog != null) {
        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("GraphQL Request Body", jsonBody, "text/plain");
    }

    return message;
}

Note: Above groovy is an example to showcase how to build CREATE/UPDATE request for GraphQL API. 

 

Conclusion

Integrating GraphQL APIs with SAP BTP Cloud Integration opens up flexible, dynamic data exchange between external applications and your SAP landscape even without a native GraphQL adapter.

By leveraging the HTTP adapter, Groovy scripting and powerful message processing tools like JSON-to-XML conversion and custom mappings, you can successfully bridge the gap.

While GraphQL‚Äôs adaptable schema presents unique integration challenges, it also enables precise and efficient data retrieval. With a clear understanding of the core concepts, tools and practical steps covered in this walkthrough, you are ready to design robust solutions for similar event-driven scenarios in your own enterprise.

Disclaimer: This is not an official reference application or documentation. The thoughts outlined in this blog are based on my real world experience and learnings.

Feel free to ‚Äúlike‚Äú, ‚ÄúShare‚Äú, ‚ÄúAdd a Comment‚Äù and to get more updates about my next blogs follow me!

 

References

  1. Official GraphQL Documentation
  2. SAP Cloud Integration Documentation (Help Portal)

entry.title: Re: What I Wish I Knew
entry.content:
When we first started our journey with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, I wish I had known the importance of early change management and key user training. The system is powerful, but its real value is unlocked only when your team truly understands the processes and how to leverage the tools.

Some tips I‚Äôd share with my former self:

  • Invest in Training Early: Don‚Äôt underestimate the learning curve, especially for configuration-heavy areas. Early and structured training for both IT and business users pays off significantly.

  • Embrace Standard Processes First: Try to adopt SAP‚Äôs best practice processes before customizing. Customizations are possible, but sticking to standard workflows accelerates adoption and reduces complexity.

  • Plan for Change Management: Regular communication, testing, and feedback loops with key users help prevent resistance and ensure smoother quarterly updates.

Overall, my advice is to focus on people and processes as much as on the technology ‚Äî the system works best when your team is confident and aligned.

entry.title: Silent Login of Fiori/UI5 Application
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I am currently working with the Fiori/UI5 application that is registered as the mashup in FSM. FSM and Workzone use the same CIS and SSO is enabled. That leads to the fact that when I open a browser, login to FSM and get to my mashup, the application is loaded perfectly.

On the other hand if I close the browser and re-open it, then navigate to FSM - I am automatically logged in since cookie/token is saved. But I can not get my application loaded - the login cookie is not passed to the Workzone and application gets halted. I have to logout manually from FSM and login back to activate the login token and make the application work again.

Is there any mechanism or approach that will help the cookie be passed after I re-open browser and FSM without logging out?

Any help or advise would be really appreciated!

Br,
Aleks.

entry.title: Multiple versions of same record in ODQMON causing delta load issue from S/4 to Informatica
entry.content:
Hi Experts, seeking your help on below issue/scenario.

Scenario - Data is being pulled into informatica system from S/4 system via CDS view. CDS view is CDC(change data capture) enabled with table elements and view elemenst.

Issue - if a same key combination single record is changed multiple times( say 3 times) between 2 deltas, then ODQMON has 3 version of same data based on timestamp. However, when it moves to Informatica system, all 3 records flow without timestamp. Timestamp isn't part of CDS view as base table doesn't have change timestamp. So, there is no way in Informatica system to identify the latest record. CDS view with CDC enablement has been created on below FICA tables
DFKKKO - has timestamp
DFKKOP 
DFKKOPK
DFKKSUM
DFKKSUMC
DFKKINVDOC_I
DFKKINVDOC_H
DFKKINVBILL_H
DFKKINVBILL_I

Any workaround or any help will be appreciated. Thank You.

entry.title: Issue with Automatic Payments
entry.content:
Problem Description
We are currently experiencing issues with the execution of automatic and single payments in SAP. Despite reviewing and adjusting the corresponding configuration, the problem persists. The only temporary solution has been to manually reassign the payable account to each vendor, which is not the expected system behavior, as it should follow the defined hierarchy and execute the payment automatically.

Error Details
When attempting to execute an automatic payment for company code 4802 (Molino San Gerardo) using bank BCOL/1645, the system displays the following error message:

‚ÄúHouse bank BCOL/1645 is not assigned to G/L account 11101020 in company code 4802.‚Äù

Account 11101020 does not belong to company code 4802 and is not included in the configuration, as confirmed during the review.

This same behavior occurs in other company codes, where the system attempts to use accounts that are not correctly assigned, resulting in similar errors.

Analysis Performed
The following reviews and tests were conducted:

  • Bank G/L accounts: Verified that the G/L accounts assigned to banks for company code 4802 are correctly configured and do not include account 11101020
  • House bank to G/L account assignment: Confirmed that house bank BCOL/1645 is linked to the correct G/L account and not to 11101020.
  • Bank determination for payments: Reviewed the configuration of bank determination for payments, confirming that company code 4802 and house bank BCOL/1645 are correctly parameterized, with no assignment to account 11101020.
    • Search for company code 4802 and house bank BCOL/1645.
    • No assignment to account 11101020 was found.
  • Tests in other company codes: When replicating the process in other company codes, similar errors were obtained, indicating that the issue is not exclusive to one company code.

Temporary Solution Applied
To execute the payment, it is currently necessary to manually assign the bank data in the vendor master record before processing the payment. However, this procedure is not viable for daily operations, as it requires manual intervention for each invoice to be paid.

Additionally, the payment is executed but impacts the statement account instead of the outgoing payment account.It posts to the account ending in 10, whereas it should post to the one ending in 12.

Support Request
We kindly request your support in identifying and correcting the root cause of this behavior so that the system performs automatic payments correctly, following the defined configuration hierarchy and without requiring manual intervention for each invoice.

Your prompt response would be greatly appreciated, as we are about to begin the integration testing phase.

entry.title: Cheaper than you think: the Commercial Model of the Event Add-On for ERP explained
entry.content:
Cheaper than you think, more flexible than you expect: the commercial model of the Event Add-On for ERP explained

In the earlier blogs of this series on the Event Add-On for ERP we had already discussed what the event add-on is about and why you would want it. This blog here is about the commercials and to a certain extent about the deployment. This is because the commercials are strongly linked to the deployment of the add-on(s) and their linkage to the Advanced Event Mesh brokers that they hand their events over to.

Event Add-On at SAP Devtoberfest: well worth watching

Before we go there, I would like to point you to two sessions that we did at Devtoverfest just a few weeks ago. You can watch the recordings and specifically the Hands-On session is well worth it. Enjoy!

  • Warp-Speed for Event Creation: Overview on the Event Add-On for ERP

  • Hands-on Session: Practical Demonstration of the Event Add-On for ERP

Commercial Aspects of the Event Add-On for ERP

With that said, let‚Äôs now look at the commercial aspects of the Event Add-On for ERP:

  • The Event Add-On for ERP is now available via CPEA, BTPEA, and PAYG.
  • It works for SAP S/4HANA and ECC to create custom events in a low code / no code way.
  • Very important: this add-on only works in combination with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh.

Why is it only available for use with Advanced Event Mesh? Because its commercials are bound to AEM. What does this mean?

  • The add-on gets activated on an AEM broker
  • You set a checkbox on your AEM broker named Add-On Connector Activation
  • This is what you get charged for ‚Äì AEM brokers activated for the Event Add-On for ERP
  • The actual add-on is downloaded and installed on your backend
  • It can only be connected to activated AEM event brokers
  • You can connect several add-ons to the same activated AEM broker
  • You get charged only for the activated broker, not the installed add-ons
  • You could for example activate one AEM broker and connect add-ons on you ECC and your SAP S/4HANA system to it. You would get charged only for the activation on your AEM broker

In fact, there is no charge other than activated AEM brokers:

  • It does not matter how many custom events are created.
  • It does not matter how many events occur.
  • It does not matter if you combine different backends.
  • There is no consumption charge or anything like that.

Are there other things to keep in mind?

  • Activated brokers are charged on a monthly basis, meaning for a month
  • In the end, you do get a kind of flat rate
  • This means as well that if you activate a broker just for a day, you get charged for the entire month.

Tiered Pricing

The add-on comes with a tiered pricing. What does this mean? In the end it means that if you activate the add-on for more AEM brokers, the price per broker gets lower for newly activated brokers in a higher tier. Important: the price for the brokers in the lower tier does not change, it is the price for the additional brokers.

Find the latest information and the calculator in the SAP Discovery Center. 

A word on the Event-Add On for ERP in the SAP Discovery Center: since the add-on is linked to AEM, you can find the pricing under AEM. Scroll down to the lower part of the Pricing screen of AEM and you will find the pricing for the add-on. It is measured by Connections which is in the end AEM brokers activated for the Event Add-On for ERP. 

 

Pricing Examples

Find some pricing examples below to give you a practical indication of how things fit together.

One connection is charged - even if multiple backends / add-ons are connected - since the activation on the broker is metered, not the number of connected backends

Two connections are charged ‚Äì since we meter the activated add-on connectors on the AEM brokers

Three connections are charged ‚Äì since we meter the activated add-on connectors on the AEM brokers and there are brokers for Dev, Q and Prod

 

Summary

The Event Add-On comes with a tiered pricing. It is metered by the number of connections to AEM brokers. The connections need to be activated on the AEM brokers. If the activated connections reach a certain minimal number, the price per active individual connections is lowered according to the specific tier.

Important: if a connection is activated in a specific month for any period of time, the full charge for that connection for the specific month applies

Find the latest information and the calculator in the SAP Discovery Center. As said, look for it in the pricing for AEM since the add-on is bound to AEM.

entry.title: SAP Signavio digital procurement transformation innovations in October 2025
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Signavio to support customers on their digital procurement transformation journey. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I‚Äôm covering:

    •  New capabilities this quarter
      • Improve Sourcing Performance with SAP Ariba with SAP Signavio Process Intelligence
      • Improvement Opportunity dashboards to increase contract consumption and prices with SAP Signavio Process Insights
      • Adherence to target processes dashboard within process landscape analysis 
    • Customer Success Stories
      • Vodafone
      • George Weston Foods
    • Upcoming Webinars and Live Sessions
      • AGCO Webinar on Nov 19
      • BME Congress in Berlin on Nov 13
    • Assets to get started

     

    New capabilities this quarter

    Improve Sourcing Performance with SAP Ariba in SAP Signavio Process Intelligence

    Problem Statement

    Sourcing managers strive to attract a broad set of existing and new suppliers for their sourcing events. This ensures a stable inflow of supply market innovations, while keeping competitive pressure high on supplier relationships.

    Inefficient sourcing processes can however discourage suppliers from submitting their bid and thus limit the chance to award the most suitable supplier in the market, matching the business requirements of the sourcing event.

    Value proposition

    As a procurement excellence or transformation leader facing limited supplier participation and lengthy sourcing cycle times the "Improve sourcing process performance in SAP Ariba" value accelerator for SAP Signavio Process Intelligence highlights potential root causes for not successfully completed sourcing projects, low supplier participation or extended process cycle times.

    Benefits

    • Reduced RfX cycle time through increased transparency on bottlenecks
    • Increased savings through increased competition of broader supplier base participation
    • Increased procurement value contribution to innovative products by attracting more qualified and innovative suppliers

    Capabilities

    • Identification of supplier drop-off points in the process
    • Root cause analysis for limited supplier participation, sourcing cycle times and process bottlenecks

     

    More information on our Help site.

    Click Demo to start step-by-step tutorial for this feature.

     

    Improvement opportunity dashboard to increase use of best possible and negotiated net prices in SAP Signavio Process Insights

    Problem statement

    Sourcing managers put a lot of effort into sourcing events, resulting in awarded supplier contracts with favorable negotiated prices & terms. Purchase orders, not using these contract terms result in lost saving potential and limited competitiveness.

    Value proposition

    Designed for procurement excellence and transformation leaders, the improvement opportunity dashboard to increase use of best possible and negotiated net prices in SAP Signavio Process Insights highlights patterns, root causes and correction recommendations of not using best available contract prices for a particular material or service.

    Benefits

    • Enhanced transparency on purchase orders without reference to contracts
    • Reduce savings leakage of not using best contracted prices

    Capabilities

    • Analyse purchase order items created without contract reference over time
    • Selection of relevant correction recommendations providing clear guidance to address issues in procurement operating model and underlying SAP ERP systems

     

    Click Demo to start step-by-step tutorial for this feature

     

     

    Improvement opportunity dashboard to increase usage of negotiated purchasing contracts in SAP Signavio Process Insights

    Problem Statement

    Sourcing managers put a lot of effort into sourcing events, resulting in awarded supplier contracts with favorable negotiated prices & terms. Purchase orders, not using these contract terms result in lost saving potential and difficult supplier negotiations, due to not consuming the contracted volumes.

    Value proposition

    Designed for procurement excellence and transformation leaders, the improvement opportunity dashboard to increase usage of negotiated purchasing contracts" in SAP Signavio Process Insights highlights patterns, root causes and correction recommendations of not using contract commitments.

    Benefits

    • Enhanced transparency on consumed volume of quantity and volume contracts
    • Benchmarking and prioritizing improvement opportunities focus resources on the areas with the highest impact
    • Pinpointing concrete savings potential through targeted correction recommendations leading directly to systematically increase contract consumption

    Capabilities

    • Show consumption patterns from release orders on volume and quantity contracts over time
    • Selection of relevant correction recommendations providing clear guidance to address issues in procurement operating model and underlying SAP ERP systems

    Click Demo to start step-by-step tutorial for this feature

     

    Adherence to target processes dashboard within process landscape analysis 

    Designed for transformation and process excellence leaders managing ERP transformations, the adherence to target processes dashboard helps balance harmonization and localization by defining a target of desired process variants and then measures deviations from the target across systems and organizational units by using SAP Signavio Process Intelligence in the process landscape analysis (plug-and-gain approach). 

     

    Click here to start a step-by-step tutorial for this feature. 

    More information regarding the Enhancements in the Process Landscape Analysis

     

    Customer Success Stories

    • Vodafone: From Insight to Action: How Vodafone Strengthens Finance Oversight with SAP Signavio 
      • Join us for an exclusive webcast with Vodafone and SAP Signavio to discover how one of the world‚Äôs leading telecommunications companies is transforming its finance function through intelligent process management.
      • What You‚Äôll Learn
        • How Vodafone is enabling finance transformation with SAP Signavio
        • The role of process intelligence in identifying and eliminating inefficiencies
        • Best practices for aligning IT and finance to drive enterprise-wide value
        • Key lessons learned from Vodafone‚Äôs journey toward scalable process excellence
      • Watch webcast recording now

     

    • George Weston Foods:
      • George Weston Foods Purchase to Pay transformation

    Upcoming Webinars and Event Sessions

    Webinar: Driving Procurement Process Excellence: The AGCO Journey, November 19th, 4pm CET

    • Join us for an inspiring session as we take a closer look at‚ÄØ AGCO‚Äôs journey toward process excellence‚ÄØ‚Äî from overcoming transformation challenges to achieving measurable business impact. 
    • In this session, you‚Äôll discover how AGCO, a global leader in agricultural machinery, partnered with‚ÄØEnnuviz‚ÄØto drive process transformation and optimize end-to-end operations using SAP Signavio solutions to provide data-driven insights and collaboration. 
    • Get a behind-the-scenes look at how AGCO tackled complexity, built resilience, and unlocked performance improvements across their‚ÄØProcure-to-Pay (P2P)‚ÄØprocesses ‚Äî and learn what‚Äôs next on their roadmap toward‚ÄØOrder-to-Cash (O2C)‚ÄØoptimization and expansion. 
    • Click here to register for free

     

    BME Symposium Einkauf und Logistik 2025 in Berlin, 13.11.2025, 9.20-10.05am CET (in German)

    SAP Ariba + SAP Signavio ‚Äì the dynamic duo for your AI-supported procurement optimization

    • Unlock value potential: Seamless collaboration along the source-to-pay process for greater efficiency and savings
    • AI as a navigator: Uncover inefficiencies, analyze causes, automatically improve processes
    • Start today: Make hidden potential in the procure-to-pay process visible and initiate the first optimizations
    • Click here to register for Symposium (on premise)  

     

    Assets to get started

    • Detailed guideline for Procurement Excellence Use Case with SAP Signavio 
    • SAP Signavio for Procurement Excellence website
      • Overview of SAP Signavio procurement capabilities, customer stories, and product tour
    • SAP Signavio Process Insights Discovery edition
      • Free one-off data load of SAP ERP transaction data for procurement process analysis
    • Overview of all SAP Signavio Procurement value accelerators

     

    • For Signavio customers:
      • to check out all the new accelerators mentioned in this blog post, access the value accelerator library, which is embedded into SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite.
      • Find the value accelerator library in the side panel of SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub and get started today. 

     

     

    We hope you found this blog post useful and look forward to your questions and feedback.

    Stay tuned for our next quarter update.

     

    Additional Information

    If you‚Äôre interested in learning more about the remaining SAP Signavio solution innovations from this quarter, check out the blog posts below:  

    • SAP Signavio November 2025 Release Highlights  
      • Value Accelerator Highlights
    • Process Analysis and Mining   
    • Process and Journey Modeling

entry.title: Re: Can we have published date earlier to template effect...
entry.content:
Hi @Ritanshi9 

Regarding your question on inactive employees it's all determined by eligibility rules + EC effective date of the template. Meaning that as long the person who is currently inactive (that you're trying to add) IS ELIGIBILE (based on eligibility rules) as of the template EC effective date then yes they can be added. It's not just the eligibility rules, it's the eligibility rule AS OF the EC effective date. Any change after the EC Effective date will not be captured when applying eligibility rules. I talk about this at the end of this blog.

Regarding your second question:

  • in a regular/leading practice compensation template where the EC publish back dates are AFTER your template's effective date, you can always run an Update all worksheets job (with "apply completed worksheets" AFTER your publish that would update the worksheets and then you would re-publish).
  • That's not possible if your EC publish back date(s) is before the template EC effective date. To prevent catastrophic outcomes to our customers in these scenarios, the product team set a blocker that will prevent any modifications through Update all worksheets job after worksheets AFTER the first publish to EC.

Hope this helps.

Xavier

entry.title: Automatic proposal of S/4 functionality for existing custom code - 'Back to Standard'
entry.content:
Hi,

Are there any tools that anyone has used to get Automatic proposal of standard S/4 functionality that could be mapped to the existing custom code. This is to enable the movement of custom code to S/4 standard functionality from a clean core perspective. I am not looking for an automatic match and convert functionality but at least something that can generate good proposals based on which the decision can be taken.

I am sure technology and relevant data/knowledge is available but surprised to find no tools (potentially AI based) available to do this in the market. Please note that I am not looking for tools to remediate custom code for which there are plenty of tools available.

Any pointers would be appreciated.

Regards,

Sharadha

entry.title: Discover what‚Äôs new in SAP Signavio‚Äôs major Process Landscape Analysis update this November
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs fast-paced ERP transformation landscape, achieving process transparency, harmonization, and efficiency is critical. Organizations migrating to SAP S/4HANA face the challenge of aligning complex business processes across multiple units while ensuring adoption of standardized templates. SAP Signavio‚Äôs Process Landscape Analysis (PLA), as part of the plug and gain approach, addresses these challenges by providing a structured, data-driven way to manage and optimize processes throughout the transformation journey. All essentials and key resources regarding plug and gain approach can be found here.

The latest update of the PLA introduces new content, an improved user experience and a completely new dashboard, making process harmonization easier and more actionable than ever. 

In this blog, you will get a high-level overview of:

  • The latest updates to Process Landscape Analysis and its new structure
  • The new Adherence to Target Processes dashboard and its key insights

 

The Process Landscape Analysis

First: what's new in the update?

The latest major PLA update delivers more and deeper content and new capabilities to track harmonization and ensure process adherence. The image below gives a clear overview of the current version and everything that will be added new. 

 

Understanding the Process Landscape Analysis 

What does this mean? To give a bit more context, let‚Äôs dive a bit more into the process landscape analysis and how it is built up. At its core, Process Landscape Analysis offers a consolidated view of the processes running in an ERP system by combining several modules of the SAP Signavio Suite. Built on three key components, it allows organizations to understand current process performance, identify process variants, and monitor adherence to target processes:

  • The Process House ‚Äì Provides a top-down structure for navigating individual processes. It aggregates information at the end-to-end process level and company level, giving stakeholders a complete overview of process execution across the organization.
  • Individual Processes ‚Äì Each process is analyzed for execution, variants, and transaction code usage. The Best-Run Score (BRS) evaluates process effectiveness and efficiency, helping identify high-volume processes that may need optimization.
  • Adherence to Target Processes Analysis ‚Äì Compares actual execution with defined target process variants to monitor compliance, enforce standardization, and support the rollout of ERP templates.

Together, these three components create a comprehensive view of your ERP processes, laying the foundation for informed decisions and a successful transformation journey. The following video shows how it looks like. 

 

Adherence to Target Processes

A cornerstone of the update is the Adherence to Target Processes dashboard, which enables organizations to track harmonization and ensure process adherence in SAP transformation projects. The dashboard comes with the following analysis:

  • Current Process Variants Analysis ‚Äì Provides a snapshot of process variants used across organizational units, highlighting inconsistencies and opportunities for standardization.
  • Comparison Against Target Processes ‚Äì Measures adherence to defined templates, revealing deviations and guiding corrective actions, such as training or process refinement.
  • Assessment of Target Processes ‚Äì Identifies rarely or never used variants, enabling deprecation and maintaining a lean ERP template.

For instance, if a rollout introduces a new procurement process, the dashboard shows which units follow the target process, where deviations occur, and which legacy variants may require retirement, ensuring operational efficiency and governance.

 

Challenge: Ensuring Consistent Execution Across Organizational Units

When customers define a template for their ERP system, they typically specify multiple process variants for each process. In each ERP system, customers are running many processes. This is called the ERP-Template. With Plug and Gain Process Landscape Analysis, customers can measure the actual process execution across more than 100 processes right out of the box.

Typical questions customers ask: 

To which extent does our actual process execution match with the ERP template? Where do we need to reinforce the rollout?

But it‚Äôs not enough to see this at a global level.. Typical customers have > 1,000 combinations of processes and organizational units. We need the transparency by process and organizational unit. That‚Äôs where the new adherence to target processes dashboard comes in!

 

Why Process Harmonization Matters

Process harmonization is essential for consistent, efficient, and compliant operations across an organization. It ensures that business processes are executed uniformly to reduce complexity, improve quality, and drive measurable business outcomes.
Successful harmonization strengthens both the top line (better customer experience, better financial results, faster execution) and the bottom line (cost reduction, standardization, and compliance). Yet, many organizations struggle to achieve this consistency, especially when multiple systems, tools, and organizational units are involved.

 

SAP Learning Journey available

In addition, we offer the following SAP Learning Journey, which provides a comprehensive guide to Process Landscape Analysis, including detailed explanations of each analysis, supporting video tutorials and how it could be applied in SAP Activate..

entry.title: Re: lms.sapsf.com Cert Renewal Notifications from SAP
entry.content:
Hi @jalpanthakkar34,

According to the KBA 2533915 - SAP SuccessFactors SSL Certificate Renewal Schedule and Public Certificate Repository - SAP for Me, in the FAQ section:

Q: How do I download or install the certificate?
A: You must have admin access to the server where you need to install the certificate. If you do not have access to your company's SSL server, notify your IT team and provide them the respective certificate download link from the above table. For SuccessFactors certificates in CPI landscape, you can follow KBA  2776681 - How to maintain SuccessFactors certificates in CPI landscape - Cloud Platform Integration‚Äù.

To perform the upload of the certificate, after downloading the certificate from the Attachments section of this KBA, it should be handed to your internal IT resources. The reason is because the certificate updates are applied on your third-party servers, and this is done by those servers' admins - which is generally deferred to the customers' IT.

BR

entry.title: Re: Successfactors - Salary review performancehistory
entry.content:
Hi @Maria851 

There is no direct mapping available between values in the standard performance history background element and columns of Compensation templates).

Here are your only choices to display performance rating history :

  • Create a custom link (will show when clicking on employee dots next to employee name) with the performance history background element.
  • Use the workaround (Perf History portlet to MDF through IC then to Comp column) documented in this blog.

I always challenge this requirement when I get it because Comp reviews are supposed to be based on the latest performance, not on your performance history. And it's all available on the employee profile already for comp planners.

All the best,

Xavier

entry.title: Re: I acquired an asset in 2022 and capitalized it on Oct...
entry.content:
Good day @ALI_HASSAN58 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Depreciation Areas, Unplanned Depreciation Expense, Manual Planning of Depreciation, Transfer Postings

Restricting Transaction Types to Depreciation Areas

The error message you provided highlights discrepancies between your transaction type year category and the acquisition posting year of your asset.

To summarise, in public cloud, the system enforces strict controls on unplanned depreciation posting to maintain compliance with IFRS and its clean-core accounting principles. The system interprets this as a prior-year acquisition and transaction types for unplanned depreciation must align with the 640 (for current-year acquisitions) and 650 (for prior-year acquisitions not prior YEARS) classification.

That means, the system will reject your posting if:

  • The wrong transaction type is used
  • You attempt to depreciate beyond the allowable residual value. An example would be depreciating more than book value minus scrap.
  • Both prior-year and current-year values exist and therefore it requires separate posting split by acquisition category.

Your 5% depreciation key scrap value setting was correct but not relevant to the manual transaction logic.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: From Data to Delight‚ÄîHow SAP CX AI Toolkit Transforms Customer Experiences
entry.content:
Introduction
As customer‚Äôs needs evolve at lightning speed, it‚Äôs more important than ever for businesses to truly tap into their data and unlock new possibilities to stay one step ahead. The SAP CX AI Toolkit is revolutionizing how organizations automate, streamline, and enhance customer interactions. By blending next-generation AI with advanced data analytics, the toolkit accelerates productivity and reveals actionable insights across sales, service, and commerce domains. Additionally, Joule‚Äîthe integrated AI copilot‚Äîoffers a seamless interface for accessing all the toolkit‚Äôs power.

Why SAP CX AI Toolkit?

SAP CX AI Toolkit bridges operational silos, bringing together CRM, email, and business systems to create efficient, role-specific workflows. With Generative AI features, it streamlines repetitive tasks, delivers proactive business intelligence, and empowers your teams to make smarter decisions‚Äîsaving you hours and driving tangible results.

Key Benefits

  • Informed Decisions: Combine enterprise and operational data to empower intelligent, data-driven choices.
  • Automated Tasks: Eliminate manual effort by automating routine actions within your team‚Äôs existing workspace‚Äîwhether in a dedicated app or through Joule.
  • Faster Customer Response: Quickly understand customer needs and respond with timely, AI-powered insights derived from comprehensive enterprise data.

Comprehensive Features & Highlights

  1. Role-Specific AI Tools
    The toolkit delivers specialized AI capabilities tailored to vital CX roles:
  • Customer communication automation
  • Summarization of records and meetings
  • Object and image recognition
  • Contextual prompts for sales, service, and marketing
    These tools enable every team to work faster and smarter.
  1. Robust Data Protection
    With best-in-class personal data protection and zero data retention policies, SAP CX AI Toolkit ensures your sensitive enterprise information remains secure and compliant.
  2. Multi-Source Data Integration
    Aggregate and analyze data from diverse systems‚ÄîSales, Service, Commerce, CDP, Microsoft 365‚Äîand unlock insights across every customer touchpoint.
  3. Configurable Tools
    From data sources to generative templates and prompts, every element is tailored to your organization‚Äôs needs, allowing a customized CX automation strategy.

Persona-Based Licensing
SAP CX AI Toolkit‚Äôs functionality is organized around three distinct licenses‚Äîusable individually or combined, based on your operational persona:

  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
  • SAP Service Cloud Version 2
  • SAP Commerce Cloud

Each license unlocks targeted features:

License Type

Key Tools & Features

All Licenses

Intelligent Q&A, Smart Actions, Meetings, Scheduling

Sales Cloud V2

Opportunity Summarization, Prospecting Emails, Discovery Call Questions

Service Cloud V2

Case Overview, Customer Service Responses, Knowledge Base Article Creation

Combined Licenses

Meeting Summaries, Follow-up Emails, Account Overviews

Commerce Cloud

Product Attributes, Descriptions, Image Generation, Visual Search, Blog & Social Posts

 

User Interfaces: Accessing SAP CX AI Toolkit
The toolkit is flexibly accessible through several user interfaces:

  • Web App: Log in using SAP or Microsoft credentials to set up your tenant and access tools as per your license. The web app features an intuitive dashboard, a searchable Q&A bar, customizable AI panels, real-time notifications, and process monitoring.
  • Chrome Extension (Joule): Installable from the Chrome Web Store, Joule places AI functionality at your fingertips across business applications like Outlook Web, SAP Cloud for Customer, and SAP Commerce Cloud. Features are context-aware and can be accessed directly as a browser overlay.
  • Embedded Panel: Integrated into SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 as a right-side panel, delivering the full web app experience in-context with contact, account, case, and opportunity data.

In-depth Feature Exploration

Intelligent Q&A
Leverages Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) to provide precise, natural-language answers to work-related questions by drawing from your enterprise sources‚Äîemails, meeting transcripts, documents, service tickets, product specs, and more. Data privacy is built-in, with no personal data stored in AI models.

Generative AI Tools
Adapted for three core ecosystems, these tools automate:

  • Microsoft 365: Meeting summaries and follow-up emails
  • SAP C4C, Sales & Service Cloud V2: Account/Opportunity summaries, prospecting emails, case overviews, customer service responses, knowledge base articles, discovery call questions
  • SAP Commerce Cloud: Blog/social media post generation, product banner text, ATP inquiries, product review summaries

SAP Commerce Cloud Features

  • AI Product Tagging: Automatically generate and enrich product attributes.
  • Product Description Generation: Create and translate compelling catalog and marketing texts.
  • Product Image Generation: Enhance images, add overlays, and edit visuals.
  • Visual Search: Find catalog products using user-uploaded images‚Äîtransforming discovery and search.

AI Tools Builder & Agents
Customize the toolkit with AI tools and intelligent agents tailored to your business needs, such as service classification, knowledge base article generation, shopping advice, quote automation, and catalog optimization.

Persona-Based Use Cases

Sales Cloud V2:

  • Combine emails, chats, and sales data for rich insights
  • Generate dynamic content for effective sales outreach
  • Quick, trustworthy answers and efficient interaction summaries
  • Personalized prospecting emails and targeted follow-up actions

Service Cloud V2:

  • Streamline case management and service responses
  • Auto-generate knowledge base content
  • Leverage smart scheduling and notifications for efficient service delivery

Commerce Cloud:

  • Enrich product content and images with AI
  • Automate catalog descriptions and visual searching
  • Drive engagement through AI-powered blog and social posts

Custom AI Tool API Support

The SAP CX AI Toolkit also empowers developers with Custom AI Tool API Support‚Äîa set of Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) that enable seamless integration of advanced, tailor-made Artificial Intelligence solutions within external applications. This means organizations can extend AI-driven outcomes to new business scenarios, connecting their unique workflows and data landscapes with the intelligence of SAP CX AI Toolkit agents.

Smarter Customer Engagement with AI Agents

SAP CX AI Toolkit features AI agents‚ÄîShopping Agent and Digital Service Agent‚Äîeach designed to address distinct phases of the customer journey.

Shopping Agent: Your Digital Sales Associate

The Shopping Agent transforms your commerce storefront by engaging customers through natural language conversations. Acting as a knowledgeable digital associate, it understands everything from specific requests‚Äîsuch as ‚ÄúI need a lightweight rain jacket‚Äù‚Äîto broader needs like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm planning a beach vacation.‚Äù The agent instantly provides tailored responses, including details about product features, compatibility, and recommendations.

Configuration is flexible, you can integrate the Shopping Agent directly into your online catalog using SAP CX AI Toolkit, and the agent converses in the customer‚Äôs language. Purpose-built for both B2B and B2C scenarios (activated via API configuration), the Shopping Agent proactively interacts with customers, refining product suggestions through relevant follow-up questions and guiding them throughout their shopping experience.

Key Capabilities of the Shopping Agent include:

  • Helping customers find and compare products using conversational AI.
  • Understanding and processing complex customer queries through intuitive dialogue.
  • Integrating seamlessly with your e-commerce storefront via a robust, flexible API.

Knowledge Base Integration:
The Shopping Agent can process unstructured data in varied formats as part of its knowledge base. By uploading product manuals, catalogs, or specification documents (PDF, image, text, spreadsheet formats, etc.) to SAP Commerce Cloud, you arm the agent with deep, detailed product knowledge to answer nuanced customer queries.

Digital Service Agent: Intelligent Post-Purchase Support

The Digital Service Agent is designed to deliver top-tier, automated customer support in natural language. Leveraging specific business knowledge sources‚Äîconfigured by your administrator‚Äîit answers post-purchase inquiries, resolving common issues and freeing up your service team for escalated cases.

This agent can operate solo or alongside the Shopping Agent, providing unified and continuous support throughout a customer‚Äôs lifecycle. For example, after a purchase, a customer with a warranty question interacts with the Digital Service Agent, who pulls relevant information‚Äîeven translating responses if needed for multilingual scenarios.

Key Capabilities of the Digital Service Agent include:

  • Operating 24/7 to provide answers using precise business knowledge sources (manuals, FAQs, service tickets).
  • Handling service-related requests such as checking order status, processing returns, or addressing product issues.
  • Assisting in both B2B and B2C environments, with API-driven flexibility.

Comparison: Shopping Agent vs. Digital Service Agent

Feature

Shopping Agent (Digital Sales Associate)

Digital Service Agent (Customer Support)

Primary Goal

Drive sales, product discovery, pre-purchase assistance

Resolve service issues, post-purchase customer support

Key Functions

Recommends products; provides features/specs/compatibility info

Answers inquiries (warranties, returns, order status); FAQs

Data Sources

Product catalog & related documents/media

Knowledge base, service tickets, admin-configured sources

Integration

Direct commerce storefront integration

Standalone or in tandem with Shopping Agent

Focus

Product- and sales-oriented

Service- and resolution-oriented

 

In essence, the Shopping Agent is your digital sales expert, while the Digital Service Agent is your first-responder customer service assistant. Integrated together, they deliver a seamless, unified customer experience across all stages of the journey.

Conclusion
SAP CX AI Toolkit is more than a set of AI tools‚Äîit‚Äôs an innovation engine for your customer experience strategy. With deep integration, robust security, and persona-driven features, businesses can transform the way data is leveraged to create exceptional customer and employee experiences. Whether accessed via the web app, Chrome extension, or embedded panels, SAP CX AI Toolkit is ready to propel enterprises into the future of AI-powered customer interactions.

entry.title: Agentic Databases for Data Scientists: SAP HANA Cloud Will Equip You with a Team
entry.content:
During my tenure as a data practitioner, I often preferred my own database to produce mission-critical calculations. The journey of such an analysis usually began with a single purpose, like informing a business process manager or a change of parameters to optimize a back-end process. Regardless of the original scope, the need to operationalize the logic often followed.

data professional in front of two monitors

Moonlighting as a DBA was nice, admittedly, because I could manage my databases with minimal process obstacles . However, the time lost searching documentation and stuck in trial-error loops of administrative commands only increased the delivery pressure, as deadlines are often unforgiving. I very quickly learned that while I was certainly capable of performing a dual role, I could not be great at both. The expectations of my job demanded data analysis excellence, while I desperately sought after administrative competency.

Last week at SAP TechEd 2025, the SAP HANA Cloud team made a few significant announcements. One very notable set of features is the introduction of the agentic database concept. Simply illustrated and grounded in my scenario, the use of AI agents could give me the best of both worlds ‚Äì autonomy and scale. Applying the example, imagine the productivity benefits associated with giving every data science professional a dedicated team of agentic colleagues ‚Äì administrator, data analyst, and a multi-model specialist.

SAP HANA Cloud agents

For those who prefer the native use of a database, consider the upcoming agentic features of SAP HANA Cloud:

  • The discovery agent provides insight into the objects within the database using a knowledge graph for more efficient semantic lookups.
  • The multi-model agent augments with the specialist knowledge needed to use the advanced analysis engines.
  • The data agent supplements the need for SQL with natural language queries.
  • The admin agent assists with the analysis and optimization of the database.

SAP HANA Cloud enhances all data professionals with agentic teammates. Thanks additionally to in-memory speed, machine learning and AI libraries, access to multi-model engines, data-tiering, and the ability to scale, this cloud database provides the much-desired resources to build autonomous, intelligent, and responsive solutions that drive business process excellence.

To learn more about functionality and availability ...

(1) Be sure to watch these TechEd 2025 virtual session replays:

SAP HANA Cloud: The Database for Business AI

Accelerating Your AI Strategy with SAP HANA Cloud

 What‚Äôs Next for SAP HANA Cloud: Road Map and Innovation Highlights

(2) Make sure to read these blogs:

SAP HANA Cloud Becomes Agentic: Introducing Discovery Agent & Data Agent

What‚Äôs Next with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì SAP TechEd 2025

Unleashing the Power of Trusted Data: SAP 2025 TechEd Announces Enhanced Data Product Capabilities

(3) Sign up for the free SAP HANA Cloud basic trial for a hands-on experience that includes a tutorial of the multi-model and data science capabilities of the database.

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
What is the take on SAP for the OR new requirement?

Oregon SB 906, which goes into effect on January 1, 2026. The law requires employers to provide a written explanation of payroll codes and related information to employees during onboarding.

 

Here‚Äôs a summary of the required disclosures:

‚Ä¢ Earnings and deductions under ORS 652.610(1)

‚Ä¢ All payroll codes used for pay rates and deductions, with detailed descriptions or definitions

‚Ä¢ A comprehensive list of all pay rates employees may be eligible for

‚Ä¢ All benefit deductions and contributions, and any deductions that may apply

‚Ä¢ The purpose of deductions that may occur during a regular pay period

‚Ä¢ Any allowances claimed as part of minimum wage

‚Ä¢ Employer-provided benefits that may appear on itemized statements as contributions or deductions

 

Employers must update this information annually by January 1.

entry.title: Configuring SAP Business Workflow for parked documents (FIPP)
entry.content:
Hello experts,

during a SAP S/4HANA implementation, we have the requirement for parked document approvals via SAP Business Workflow (object type FIPP). As I am new to this topic, I need advice on the following issue:

So far, I did the configuration in customizing under ‚ÄòMake and Check Settings for Document Parking‚Äô, I created the workflow variant, assigned company code and defined release approval paths and procedures for parking documents including mentioning needed subworkflow WS51000020 (FIPP_SUBWFN2, two step approval except initiator). Also, I defined users for release authorizations for each approval level in OBWF. Beforehand, I activated the type linkage in transaction SWE2 for workflow framework WS00400032 for event CREATED as well as event linking in transaction OOCU is activated.

When I create a document with transaction FB01 and save it as completed, I check afterward in FBV3 and see the document is not released as expected. When I check workflow -> workflow overview, I see that workflow is not going through as expected. In display workflow log, I check the error message in work item and it says error in workflow customizing for document parking in OBWE. I checked the transaction and related customizing, but I am unable to find the hidden mistake.

Does anyone have an advice on how to solve this issue? Is this anything else to consider?

Thank you in advance for any advice on this matter

Kind regards

Jonas

entry.title: SAP TRM Daily Compounding Interest Calculation
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am trying to use SAP TRM on public cloud to calculate daily compounding interest in the same way as my Excel model. In Excel, each day‚Äôs interest is calculated on the sum of the original principal plus all previously accrued (unpaid) interest, so the interest compounds daily. However, in SAP, I am getting different results‚ÄîSAP seems to be calculating interest only on the original principal, not including the previous day‚Äôs accrued interest in the base.

Excel Calculation Logic:

  • Each day‚Äôs interest base: Principal + Previous Day‚Äôs Cumulative Interest
  • Formula: Base Interest = (Principal + Previous Day‚Äôs Int Cmpd Bal) √ó Rate √ó Days / 360
  • This means the interest compounds daily, and the interest amount grows slightly each day as it is calculated on a growing balance

Difference in SAP currently: Each day‚Äôs interest = Principal √ó Rate / 360 (Previous interest is not included in the base)

I want SAP to calculate daily interest so that each day‚Äôs interest is based on the sum of the principal plus all previously accrued interest (i.e., true daily compounding), matching my Excel model. The goal is for SAP to use the previous day‚Äôs cumulative balance as the new base for interest calculation.

  • Is there a way to configure SAP so that it compounds interest daily, using the previous day‚Äôs cumulative balance as the new base for interest calculation?
  • Are there specific settings, calculation methods, or configuration steps in SAP that need to be enabled or adjusted to achieve this?
  • Has anyone successfully set up daily compounding interest in SAP to match this Excel logic? If so, could you share the configuration steps or any tips?

Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: Re: MRP Planning Issue
entry.content:
Hello

 

Why do you need to have MRP type ND your finished product? Components will only be planned if you have dependent requirements and dependent requirements will only be created if you have a planned order for the finished product, so it does not really make sense to use ND.

entry.title: Re: ABAP RAP - Enable/Disable Static Action on Child enti...
entry.content:
@Praveen547 

1. You can use the Feature Control to enable the button when the entity is in draft status (using the %is_draft field).

METHOD get_instance_features.
  LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(ls_key).
    IF ls_key-%is_draft = if_abap_behv=>mk-on.
      "enable the action
    ELSE.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDMETHOD.

2.  You can set SideEffects annotations for unbound actions in the annotations.xml file.

Please see the section Defining Side Effects on Unbound Actions in the document below:

https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/sdk/#/topic/18b17bdd49d1436fa9172cbb01e26544

entry.title: How to Manual restriction of Transport import
entry.content:
We want to restrict the manual import of tr. Currently basis uses charm to import the TR to production. 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to Manual restriction of Transport import
entry.content:
Hi,

If the TR is managed by ChaRM document, then by default, it can only be imported via ChaRM. We have a project switch concept to control if the TR could be manually imported via STMS or not. Refer to KBA: 0002211597 for more details of the CTS project switch. This switch is closed for all systems by default when you create task list for the cycle.

BR

entry.title: Re: Payguide(salary ranges) are getting adjusted on the b...
entry.content:
Hi @Ritanshi9 ,

My understanding is that for this tag, it is expected that since it is set to false it is removed from the xml.  The behaviour of the template should still follow a false flag.  Please advise if you are seeing different behaviour.

Another option to explore is the use of a custom FTE field to display true FTE but setting the standard field to 1 (which is default if not used).  This blog and associated comments/questions is extremely thorough, so I suggest you review if you haven't already FTE and Proration examples in Compensation - SAP Community

Hope that helps.

Christian

entry.title: Re: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 1: Environment Setup
entry.content:
@BharathKumarVaddepalli 

Hi Bharath,

You should configure the destination in your BTP cockpit first using the Sales Order OData V4 API:
üëâ SAP API Business Hub ‚Äì CE_SALESORDER_0001

Scroll down to API Resources, where you‚Äôll find the configuration details for the production URL. Use that as your System URI in the destination settings.
Once the destination is successfully created and tested, you can reference it directly in your Joule action project ‚Äî no need to include the full API path inside the destination.

Hope this clarifies it!

‚Äî Teng Teng
